data.body: Consider the Wheatstone bridge circuit comprising four resistors \( R_1 \), \( R_2 \), \( R_3 \), and \( R_4 \). A source is connected across points A and C, forming the battery arm. A galvanometer \( G \) is connected between vertices B and D, forming the galvanometer arm.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: In the balanced bridge scenario, where \( I_g = 0 \) (current through the galvanometer), Kirchhoff's junction rule applied to junctions D and B gives us \( I_1 = I_3 \) and \( I_2 = I_4 \).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Applying Kirchhoff's loop rule to closed loops ADBA and CBDC, we get:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[\begin{aligned}-I_1 R_1 + I_2 R_2 &= 0 \\I_2 R_4 - I_1 R_3 &= 0\end{aligned}\]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This equation, known as the balance condition, ensures zero deflection in the galvanometer.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The Wheatstone bridge, along with its balance condition, provides a practical method for determining unknown resistances. data.name: paragraph
data.body: This principle is used in practical devices like the meter bridge.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The Wheatstone bridge offers a simple yet effective way to measure unknown resistances, making it a valuable tool in electrical engineering and experimentation.
